properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain will gradually come to an end over eastern portions of mainland Nova Scotia after midnight, and early Wednesday morning over Cape Breton. Total rainfall amounts of 25 and 50 mm are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-24T08:59:05-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and ice pellets with a risk of freezing rain expected tonight and Wednesday. A second shot of winter weather on Thursday and Friday. A mixture of ice pellets, snow, and occasional freezing rain is expected tonight and Wednesday. Although amounts may not be enough to require a warning, travel will still be hazardous in these areas. Please consider postponing non-essential travel. Another storm is forecast to affect Newfoundland on Thursday and early Friday. This feature is expected to track a little further south than tonight's system. It appears significant snowfall is possible for parts of the West Coast, the Northeast Coast, the East Coast as well as central Newfoundland. Warnings will likely be required for the Thursday/Friday event. Further details will be provided in subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-24T09:05:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-24T01:06:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0759350335.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bonavista Peninsula, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of rain associated with a very slow moving weather system will persist over the province for today and tonight. Total rainfall amounts of 40 to 70 mm are expected by this evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Update: Flood Warning Continues For The Red River From Emerson To The Red River Floodway Channel Inlet
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre continues to issue a Flood Warning on the Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet due to high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-04-24T09:30:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-04-23T09:43:18-05:00, C7B639DD-8506-8A23-4971-663CA08A4036
Area: Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Strong easterly winds in the Wreckhouse area with gusts reaching 110 km/h will further increase to 140 km/h after midnight. Winds are expected to diminish below warning criteria Wednesday morning. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Additional rainfall amounts of 10 mm are possible today. This will bring total rainfall amounts up to 50 mm by this afternoon. The highest rainfall amounts are expected over southern portions of the region, including Timmins. The rain will change over to snow this afternoon. Lesser rainfall amounts are anticipated for northern sections of the region where more snow will fall. Over northern sections including Cochrane precipitation is expected to fall mainly as snow with local amounts possibly reaching 15 cm by this afternoon. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-24T06:50:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-23T14:51:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0756171041.2019
Area: Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels are expected near the coast this morning. Coastal flood warning issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2019-04-24. A low pressure system from the Great Lakes will bring moderate to strong winds over the Quebec City area Wednesday morning. These winds combined with the high flow of the St Lawrence River and the current run of high-amplitude tidal ranges could cause minor flooding along the coast in and around the following localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Daylight Time). Quebec City: 2019-04-24, from 09:00 AM to 12:00 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-24T17:59:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-24T02:08:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1855923017.2019
Area: Québec area, Côte-de-Beaupré - L'Île d'Orléans area, Bellechasse area, Lévis area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Light snow is expected to begin overnight and will become heavy, at times, by Wednesday morning. Snow will likely mix with ice pellets Wednesday afternoon. Total accumulations of 15 to 20 cm are forecast before the snow tapers off Wednesday evening. Conditions will improve Wednesday night, but are expected to deteriorate again on Thursday as another area of low pressure approaches Newfoundland. This system will likely bring a second round of significant snowfall from Thursday afternoon through Friday morning. Snowfall warnings are likely to be required for this event as well. Additional details will be provided in subsequent forecasts. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-24T17:06:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-24T01:07:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2729967398.2019
Area: Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain overnight tonight and Friday. Avalon Peninsula and Clarenville area: Scattered flurries are expected to develop overnight and change to freezing rain or ice pellets by early Wednesday morning. Freezing rain will transition to rain over the southern Avalon Peninsula by midday Wednesday and in the afternoon elsewhere. Precipitation will likely remain as freezing rain in the Clarenville area. South Coast: Rain will change to freezing rain overnight. Most areas along the coast will transition back to rain Wednesday morning or afternoon, while inland and higher elevation areas will see mainly freezing rain. Another storm is forecast to affect Newfoundland on Thursday and early Friday. This feature is expected to track a little further south than tonight's system. A variety of snow, ice pellets and potentially freezing rain are anticipated for parts of the South Coast, Burin Peninsula, and northern Avalon Peninsula. Warnings will likely be required for the Thursday/Friday event. Further details will be provided in subsequent forecasts. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-24T10:09:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-24T01:10:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0975604474.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Clarenville and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A deep low pressure system continues to influence the Yukon. A strong pressure gradient will cause very strong winds of 80 km/h gusting to 100 near the Richardson Mountains. Combined with light snow, these winds will cause extensive blowing snow and reduce visibility to near zero. These blizzard conditions will persist through to Wednesday evening. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-24T14:35:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-23T22:36:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1620152543.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: Air Quality Due To Wildfire
properties.Summary:
Description: The wildfire continues to burn southwest of Biggar. The State of Emergency is still active due to poor air quality due to shifting smoke from the fire. Emergency services personnel request that citizens stay away from the area.
Expires: 2019-04-23T23:45:00-06:00
